DataElement.preferredDefinition: A description of the localization technique that was performed.

DataElementConcept.preferredDefinition: The process of determining or marking the location or site of a lesion or disease._A practiced and regimented skill or series of actions._Executed and carried through to completion.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: The act or task of directed movement from one location to another.: Endoscopic examination of the tracheobronchial tree.

Concepts.definition: The act or task of directed movement from one location to another.
Endoscopic examination of the tracheobronchial tree.

PermissibleValues.value: Perilesional dye injection, e.g. Methylene blue

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A synthetic basic dye. Methylene blue stains to negatively charged cell components like nucleic acids; when administered in the lymphatic bed of a tumor during oncologic surgery, methylene blue may stain lymph nodes draining from the tumor, thereby aiding in the visual localization of tumor sentinel lymph nodes. When administered intravenously in low doses, this agent may convert methemoglobin to hemoglobin.

Concepts.definition: A synthetic basic dye. Methylene blue stains to negatively charged cell components like nucleic acids; when administered in the lymphatic bed of a tumor during oncologic surgery, methylene blue may stain lymph nodes draining from the tumor, thereby aiding in the visual localization of tumor sentinel lymph nodes. When administered intravenously in low doses, this agent may convert methemoglobin to hemoglobin.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A procedure that uses ultrasound (high-energy sound waves that are bounced off internal tissues and organs) during surgery. Sonograms (pictures made by ultrasound) of the inside of the body are viewed on a computer to help a surgeon find tumors or other problems during the operation.

Concepts.definition: A procedure that uses ultrasound (high-energy sound waves that are bounced off internal tissues and organs) during surgery. Sonograms (pictures made by ultrasound) of the inside of the body are viewed on a computer to help a surgeon find tumors or other problems during the operation.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Used as a fixed standard of reference for comparison or measurement.

Concepts.definition: Used as a fixed standard of reference for comparison or measurement.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A substance containing a radioisotope that has an affinity for and binds to a chosen biologic substance of interest to enable quantification of biologic processes.

Concepts.definition: A substance containing a radioisotope that has an affinity for and binds to a chosen biologic substance of interest to enable quantification of biologic processes.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Different than the one(s) previously specified or mentioned.

Concepts.definition: Different than the one(s) previously specified or mentioned.

ValueMeaning.administrativeNotes: 2023.2.2 Alt VM added per ticket request CADSR0002006. ak

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A nontoxic, fluorescent, tricarbocyanine dye with a peak spectral absorption at 790 nm, with application in determining cardiac output, hepatic function, liver blood flow, as well as ophthalmic angiography. Upon administration, indocyanine green (ICG) rapidly binds to its principle carrier, plasma protein, and is thereby confined to the vascular space. This agent, with a half-life of 150 to 180 seconds, is removed exclusively by the liver from circulation to bile juice. Furthermore, due to poor uptake, ICG is not suitable for angiography or functional output analysis of kidney, lung, cerebro-spinal, or peripheral tissues.

Concepts.definition: A nontoxic, fluorescent, tricarbocyanine dye with a peak spectral absorption at 790 nm, with application in determining cardiac output, hepatic function, liver blood flow, as well as ophthalmic angiography. Upon administration, indocyanine green (ICG) rapidly binds to its principle carrier, plasma protein, and is thereby confined to the vascular space. This agent, with a half-life of 150 to 180 seconds, is removed exclusively by the liver from circulation to bile juice. Furthermore, due to poor uptake, ICG is not suitable for angiography or functional output analysis of kidney, lung, cerebro-spinal, or peripheral tissues.
